newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgium's Cockerill plunges into loss in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Belgium's Cockerill plunges into loss in 1996.

text.p: Belgium's largest steel maker Cockerill Sambre said on Wednesday it plunged into the red in 1996, weighed down by an extraordinary loss, but it was hopeful of a small profit in 1997.
Cockerill booked a 9.00 billion franc group loss in 1996, reversing a 3.2 billion franc net profit in 1995, partly because of a 7.7 billion franc exceptional loss.
The company said it had made six billion francs of provisions to cover a part of its "Horizon 2000" plan, which aims to make the company competitive and which will entail 2,000 job losses.
Consolidated turnover dipped slightly to 203.1 billion francs from 206.7 billion a year earlier, while crude steel production edged up to 6.35 million tonnes from 6.33 million.

"Steel prices have fallen throughout 1996 and the first quarter of 1997 started with very low prices. Steel price rises have been registered for second-quarter deliveries. If this trend continues, integrated steel results would become positive again in 1997," Cockerill said.
Cockerill also said that profits of its distribution and building divisions should compensate for the losses which could continue to hit its mechanical and automobile equipment divisions.
It added that the group should start to fully benefit from the positive impact of its competitivity plan in 1998.
Because of the large 1996 loss, Cockerill said it would pay no dividend. The group paid a gross dividend of 25.6 francs per preferred share on 1995 earnings.
"If there is a little profit in 1997, there will be a dividend, though perhaps not a full one," Cockerill chairman Jean Gandois said.
He also said that an alliance with another group was a possibility for the long term.
However Cockerill would have to become more competitive before he would enter into any partnership negotiations.

Asked whether he feared Cockerill would be left isolated after the merger of the steel divisions of German industry giants Krupp and Thyssen, he said: "I don't fear isolation. I'm ready to negotiate (for a partner) when it appears necessary."
This could be "sooner than previously thought".
"I think there are some people who would be interested but I want to have made progress on Cockerill's Horizon 2000 plan first," he added.
